Having been given by Ford funds with which to hire a large and go-getting
fund-raising staff, the Center has most fund sources pretty well cornered, it
seems. They, in turn, have engaged or retained most of the best available
fund-raising firms.
Roughly (here a double-edged word) I guess it all reduces itself to money.
White has (as he says frequently) some eleven million, with it growing
every day. This is a new *'ethic* * for a chap like Skomia who had normally
not always evaluated progress in quite such fiscal terms.
We hope to have a "proposal** from White along these lines soon, as I men¬
tioned . This will be discussed by our Board in Columbus along with his
"network merger" proposal. To attract us it must at least contain provision
for the NAEB*s continuance as an entity (electing its own officers and direc¬
tors) as much as possible, and assurance of adequate fiscal support for the
future. Even then, of course, I have misgivings. Perhaps we may yet
"strike'* funds in time to say "no thanks** with more confidence and firmness
than we have recently been able to muster. It*s a little difficult to dislodge
"faits accomplis" of the dimensions now confronting us. This includes the
Center's plans (with Ford funds and support) for Washington — which include
not one but several lawyers, etc.
As I seem to say each time, lately, we hope to know more about all this
soon. I wish the story were brighter right now. And thanks for your under¬
standing and interest.
Sincerely,
Harry J. Skomia
President
